p.s: The author John Worne tries to convince the reader by using several stylistic devices.
The headline Language learning in the UK: can't, won't is memorable because of the alliteration language learning and the parallelism can't, won't, don't, which words all end the same way.
The introduction a part of the headline is used to explain its meaning and to make it more interesting and eye-catching for the reader.
In this part Worne uses inclusive language and writes about our national view to include the reader and appeal to them directly.
Through the whole article Worne a lot of studies and presents evidence to his theses, for example the exam results (l. 7) or the most recenrecent CBI/Pearson Education and Skills Survey (l. 19).
This persuades the reader into thinking the article is more valid, because of the presented evidence and the opinion of the author is justified by something logical.
Therefore the reader might believe Worne more easily.
To make the editorial more interesting the author uses an Alliterationalliteration menu in more (l. 6).
The arguments of his possible opponents are weakened by using irony and a hyperbole in line 15 wearable tech will enable intercultural telepathy anyway.

This witty tone is strengthened by short comments of the author, which builds and antithesis to the thesis mentioned before, for example everyone speaks English in the world of business (they don't) (l. 13).
To emphasise the importance of learning foreign languages, John Worne uses an Anaphoraanaphora and Alliterationalliteration language learning...language (l. 16-17).
Furthermore he strengthens his point by using repititionsrepetitions, for example the tough reality in a tough job (l. 27) or a pure lawyer or a pure linguist (l. 28-29).
the next part the antithesis is used to emphasize John Worne's view.
He states the UK needs more of our young people, not fewer (l. 30).
In the ending the author appeals to the reader or to be more specific the parents directly.
He claims that the parents are responsible for shifting the culture at home.
This can lead to an emotional reaction like guilt and by appealing the reader directly they get included and might believe John Worne more easily.
Through the whole text the author uses formal language to show the reader he is valid.
In a few parts he switches to colloquial language to address more people and to simplify his arguments, for example Cobblers (l. 15).
All in all the author uses many stylistic devices and persuasive techniques to make his article more interesting and believable.
